title: How to Grill Corn in the Husk

steps.headline: Pick fresh, firm ears of corn to grill.
steps.description: Look for ears of corn that have a sweet smell and are firm to the touch when you pick them up. Check the hair-like tassels on the top of each ear to make sure they are yellow instead of dark brown or black. Choose as many ears of corn as you need for you and any others you're serving. The color of the kernels doesn't matter as long as the corn is fresh.Tip: Many grocery stores sell fresh corn while it's in season. Otherwise, you may be able to buy some directly from local growers.

steps.headline: Peel the husks back without completely removing them.
steps.description: Grab the husk on top of the ear of corn and slowly pull it down toward the bottom. Work back each layer of husk individually so it's easier to take off. Continue pulling back the layers without tearing the husk off until you expose the corn kernels underneath. It's okay if some of the husks break off while you're peeling the corn as long as it can still cover the kernels.

steps.headline: Trim the silk off of each corn cob.
steps.description: The final layer of the husk is usually made of hair-like strands, known as the silk. Use a pair of kitchen scissors to cut the silk near the base at the bottom of the cob. Try to remove as much of the silk as you can so you don't have to worry about taking it off later. Run your hand over the corn kernels to catch any loose silk that still may be sticking to it. You can wait until after you grill the corn to remove the silk if you want.

steps.headline: Add butter and seasonings to the corn if you want.
steps.description: Soften 1 teaspoon (4.7 g) of butter for each ear of corn you plan on grilling. Spread the butter thinly across the kernels with a knife or cooking brush, rotating the ear of corn so you get an even application. Sprinkle a pinch of salt onto the corn after the butter so it sticks to the corn. Make sure your butter isn't completely melted when you apply it or else it will drip or leak out. You can also add other spices if you want, such as pepper, cayenne, or garlic salt. Use a pinch at a time so the flavors aren't too overwhelming. You can also choose to wait until you grill the corn to add your seasonings if you want.

steps.headline: Pull the husks back into place before cooking them.
steps.description: Carefully pull the husks back over the kernels so they're covered. Squeeze the husks around the corn cob so they stick to the butter and make a tighter seal. The husks will be a little looser around the corn, but they will still cook through evenly. Set the corn on a cooking tray so you can easily carry them to your grill. If you want some of the corn kernels to have char marks, leave a 1 inch (2.5 cm) strip of them exposed.

steps.headline: Preheat your grill to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Light your grill and close the lid so it can heat up completely. Let the grill preheat until it's about 350 °F (177 °C) inside so your corn will cook thoroughly and evenly. Use the thermometer built into the grill's lid or one you have in your kitchen so you know the temperature. Use an oven mitt while you're checking the temperature so you don't burn yourself.

steps.headline: Place the ears of corn directly on the grill grate.
steps.description: Use a pair of tongs to transfer the corn from the baking tray to the grill. Set them over direct heat with about 1 inch (2.5 cm) in between each ear so the heat can cook them evenly. As soon as you put all of your corn on the grill, immediately close the lid so you don't lose any more heat. You can also use a baking tray or wrap the corn in foil, but you won't get the char marks from your grill.

steps.headline: Turn the corn every 5 minutes so it cooks evenly.
steps.description: As the corn cooks, the husks will start to burn and char. Rotate the ears of corn by a quarter turn after they've been on the grill for 5 minutes. Continue checking the corn every 5 minutes and spinning the ears so they get an even cook on each side. If you want char marks on some of the corn kernels, then put the strip of kernels you left exposed face-down during your last rotation.Warning: Don't leave the corn unattended while you're cooking it since it could burn easily.

steps.headline: Take your corn off the grill after 25-30 minutes and let them cool for 5 minutes.
steps.description: After you've cooked the corn for 25-30 minutes, use your tongs to take the ears off of the grill and set them on a serving plate. Leave the corn on your serving plate for at least 5 minutes so you don't burn yourself while you try to remove the husks. If you're letting your corn sit for a while before serving it, cover the plate with aluminum foil so it doesn't get cold.

steps.headline: Peel the husks back to expose the cooked corn.
steps.description: Once your corn has cooled down after cooking it, grab the top of the husk and pull it back slowly. Be careful since the corn and husk will be hot when you're trying to remove it. Once you peel back the husk, you can break it off and throw it away since it's not edible.Tip: Keep a trash can nearby so you can throw away the husk after you remove it.

steps.headline: Add butter and seasonings to the corn if you didn't earlier.
steps.description: Spread softened or melted butter across the corn kernels to add flavor to them. Sprinkle a pinch of salt on each of the ears of corn for additional seasoning and make them taste better. If you want, you can also add pinches of other spices, such as pepper, cayenne, paprika, or garlic salt to help enhance the flavor. If you added butter and seasoning before you cooked the corn, you can either skip this step or add more if you'd like. You don't need to add any butter or salt to your corn if you don't want to.

steps.headline: Eat the corn directly on the cob or cut it off.
steps.description: Once the corn is cooked and seasoned, take bites of the corn while it's still on the cob, working down the length of the ear. If you aren't able to or don't want to eat from the cob, stand the ear of corn up and use a chef's knife to cut from the top to the bottom. Try to cut as close to the cob as you can so you don't waste any kernels. If you have any leftovers, store them in an airtight container for up to 1 week.
